oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Patterson Forge, or Montgomery Bell Tunnel, Cheatham County, Tennessee, 1977 August
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the water tunnel in Cheatham County known as Patterson’s Forge, or Montgomery Bell Tunnel. The historic marker near the tunnel describes the site as “4.1 mi. northwest, at The Narrows, Montgomery Bell, pioneer industrialist, ironmaster, philanthropist and turfman, built a forge in 1818. Power was obtained by tunneling water through the hill at the top of the Narrows to a point below it where the river returns after making a 7-mile horseshoe bend.” It is around 290 foot long through limestone rock which was the first “full-scale” water diversion tunnel built in the United States. The site is a part of the Narrows of the Harpeth State Historic Area maintained by the Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation. It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1994. Forms part of the Claynita Harris Slide Collection. The original is a 35 mm color transparency (2 x 2 in. slide mount)
